verses.text: Let every person be subject to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except from God, and those that exist have been established by God.
verses.comment: Paul teaches that all civil authorities have their origin and legitimacy from God Himself. There is an implicit call to order, hierarchy, and respect for divinely instituted structures, reflecting the importance of visible authority even within the church. This mirrors Jesus' teaching before Pilate (John 19:11) that authority comes from above.

verses.text: Therefore, whoever resists the authority resists what God has appointed, and those who resist will incur judgment.
verses.comment: Rebelling against lawful authority is portrayed as rebellion against God’s will. This shows that both civic and spiritual authority have divine foundation and should be respected except when contrary to God's higher law (see Acts 5:29).

verses.text: For rulers are not a terror to good conduct, but to bad. Would you have no fear of the one who is in authority? Do what is good, and you will receive approval;
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes the positive function of authority: protecting moral order. This parallels instructions in 1 Peter and highlights the importance of cooperation with established structures for the sake of peace and conscience.

verses.text: for he is God’s servant for your good. But if you do wrong, be afraid, for he does not bear the sword for nothing. For he is the servant of God, an avenger who carries out God’s wrath on the wrongdoer.
verses.comment: Here, Paul calls rulers 'God’s servant' or 'diakonos,' which points toward a divinely appointed mediator. The judicial role of authority echoes Old Testament teaching on God's use of human agents to uphold justice.

verses.text: Therefore, it is necessary to submit, not only because of fear of punishment but also for the sake of conscience.
verses.comment: Obedience is not just about avoiding consequence, but about acting in accordance with a well-formed conscience. The written law is seen as intimately linked to the heart and mind, echoing Old Testament prophecy about the law being written on our hearts (Jer. 31:33).

verses.text: For this reason you also pay taxes, for the authorities are God’s ministers, attending continually to this very thing.
verses.comment: Paul aligns with Jesus’ teaching to 'render to Caesar what is Caesar’s.' Taxes, like other civic duties, are seen as part of obeying God's ministers, underscoring a spiritual dimension to daily life.

verses.text: Pay to all what is owed to them: taxes to whom taxes are owed, revenue to whom revenue is owed, respect to whom respect is owed, honor to whom honor is owed.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes justice and integrity in all relationships, reflecting wisdom literature's teaching that we are to render to each what is due, not just material but also spiritual respect and honor.

verses.text: Owe no one anything, except to love one another, for the one who loves another has fulfilled the law.
verses.comment: Paul highlights love as the debt that is never fully paid and as the fulfillment of the law. This links to Jesus’ summary of the law and His commandment on love (John 13:34), emphasizing both the letter and spirit of the law.

verses.text: For the commandments, 'You shall not commit adultery, you shall not murder, you shall not steal, you shall not covet,' and any other commandment, are summed up in this word: 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.'
verses.comment: Paul restates several commandments from the Decalogue, showing that loving one's neighbor completes the underlying intent of the law. The order of commandments reflects their enduring moral authority.

verses.text: Love does no harm to a neighbor; therefore love is the fulfillment of the law.
verses.comment: Loving actively means not causing harm; this summary shows the moral law is still relevant and fulfilled by genuine charity. This verse encapsulates a spiritual reading of the commandments, calling for both external and internal obedience.

verses.text: And do this, understanding the present time, that it is already the hour for you to wake from sleep. For now our salvation is nearer than when we first believed.
verses.comment: Paul stresses the urgency of conversion—Christian life is a continual awakening to grace and readiness for the final coming of Christ. Early church tradition often linked this passage with the sacrament of spiritual awakening and perseverance.

verses.text: The night is far gone; the day is at hand. So let us cast off the works of darkness and put on the armor of light.
verses.comment: Darkness and light represent sin and righteousness. The call to 'put on' the armor of light is likely a baptismal allusion and the call to sanctification, which was viewed as both a moment and a lifelong process of transformation.

verses.text: Let us walk decently, as in the daytime, not in revelry and drunkenness, not in sexual immorality and debauchery, not in quarreling and jealousy.
verses.comment: Paul uses vivid language to describe the sins to be rejected as unworthy of those in the light of Christ. Christians are called to visible holiness, both in public and private life.

verses.text: But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh, to gratify its desires.
verses.comment: To 'put on Christ' is a call to be united with Jesus, to participate in His life and grace—a theme deeply rooted in the church from the earliest creeds. This points to the necessity of responding to grace in daily conduct and walking in union with Christ.
